reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Time Chain Book 1
reviews.reviewText: Time Chain Book 1 The author does a great job of weaving the storyline and following the characters from one timeline to another. It is definitely the read and I can't wait to read the next book to see what happens to the characters.I'm downloading the next one after I finish my review.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Surprised but good story
reviews.reviewText: Always interested in Ireland and of course Time travel. So purchased. Was a little surprised in the direction after a few chapters. But overall good story.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Interesting Concept But Not Well Developed
reviews.reviewText: I don't read much fiction, but I'm trying to diversify at my advanced age. This book started out fairly well, but the plot twists became repeatedly predictable. The ending, a weak, quickie solution to what was a very serious dilemma. The Epilogue kind of made the end worthwhile. I did buy all 3 of the books and have to admit that book 2 is bordering on just plain silly. I'm kind of just scrolling though it. Then, there's book 3.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars It’s fine, but inconsistent; five stars for trying though
reviews.reviewText: First off, I just want to say that I am giving this book 5 stars for a variety of reasons. I enjoy most time travel books. Also, although I don’t think this one is technically self-published, it’s definitely self-published adjacent. Those two facts give the book a higher starting point than it would otherwise, and it is good enough to retain a 5 star rating. However, the most salient part of the review might be this: this is the first book of a series, but I don’t know if I want to read the next one.I liked the way this book handles time travel conceptually, but I think that other reviewers have correctly pointed out that it doesn’t really make any sense. Without getting into the details too much, the book makes it pretty clear that Aideen is on the island by herself for about fifty years and has participated in many (up to 180 or so) missions in that time. But they never explain who was sending the travelers to her, or acknowledge that inconsistency. Key parts of the book also center around what exactly happens when changes are made in the past, and who notices the changes. But at the end, two very important plot points rely on two very different things happening in such a case (in one case, the future changes immediately and only the travelers notice; in the other, things hadn’t changed yet, but would soon in a noticeable way for everyone).Finally, I wanted to point out something I found funny. The book takes place in Ireland, and we meet several Irish women with traditional Irish names. There are several times in the book where Dani meets a woman, and then the woman says something like, “My name is Aoife. It’s a strange name I know. It’s spelled ‘Aoife’ but it’s pronounced ‘Ee-fa’.” I’m sure it’s helpful for readers who are unfamiliar with the names, but the dialog comes across as very unnatural. I would prefer a glossary or pronunciation guide at the beginning of the book or even a footnote. Or just give the women easier to pronounce names.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great Book! Loved it!
reviews.reviewText: Great book! Easy reading, I enjoyed this and will now embark on book 2 of the series! Looking forward to see what happens next and routing for the main characters!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2024
reviews.reviewText: One of the best time travel books I have read. This tale makes you believe it is possible to go to the future and back. Well written. Great characters. Thanks.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 2.0 out of 5 stars Nothing against the author
reviews.reviewText: The author seems like a likable fellow and I always feel bad when giving a harsh review that might get back to the author and make him unhappy. But, I also want to be honest about the book. Time travel is a very competitive subject these days and there is loads of material out there in the form of books, series and films. A few are excellent; some just run of the mill and some awful. I find this story falls into the middle group. There is nothing in the story that makes it stand out. It is not very clever, funny and there are quite a few plot holes. It is apparent that science is not a strong point with the author and it shows in the story. This story reads more like a world travel vacation than science fiction. The whole time travel theme seems to be inserted as an afterthought. The story is more about the relationship between the two girls and what they see. Also, if one is going to tackle time travel, there needs to be a strong passion and research into history. Only going back to the 70’s just does not cut it no matter how you explain it into the story. One does not have to do time travel to write an acceptable story about the past and present. Without a strong background in history and science this author needs to rethink what he will write about.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Imaginative Time Travel Story
reviews.reviewText: Sometimes confusing, but fast paced time travel story set initially in West Ireland. Intrigue, danger , and a look at time periods from 1753-2553. A very different , but positive look at the World.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 26, 2023
reviews.reviewText: This was a very interesting variation of a time travel adventure. The descriptions of life in the future showed great imagination.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great fun. looking forward to the next novel.
reviews.reviewText: Spend a few hours losing yourself in the complexities of time travel on a journey with Steven Decker. Can’t imagine where the story will go in the next novel but it will be worth waiting for.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 3, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I love time travel novels but not this one. 1978 for goodness sake - seemed to be simply for the sex and alcohol. Only got 20% in and dropped it at the same sex romance. Felt like a badly written story by a school kid.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 28, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Starts out fine, but then gets like a skipping record, leaving out vital explanations before jumping to the next bit of plot. I’ve read lots of time travel, but this one, frankly, didn’t work.
